messages.subject: KINKI NIHONTO GAKKAI
messages.msgSnippet: All, I have had a member as me about a kanteisho from a group known as the KINKI NIHONTO GAKKAI. The paper is signed by a Mr KORYU TERAMINE ( Teramune ? ) Does
messages.messageBody:
All, I have had a member as me about a kanteisho from a group known as
the KINKI NIHONTO GAKKAI. The paper is signed by a Mr KORYU TERAMINE (
Teramune ? ) Does anyone have any information on this group ?, is it a
Shop perhaps ?.

Cheers

Rich Turner

messages.messageBody:
Sorry:

Still working on the photos. Real world keeps getting in the way!

This message is intended only for the use of the individual or entity to which it is addressed and may contain information that is privileged, confidential and exempt from disclosure. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination, distribution or copying of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you have received this communication in error, please notify us immediately by telephone and return the original to us by mail at Grandone Public Relations, 403 Jefferson Road, Edwardsville, IL 62025.
Thank you.

----- Original Message -----
From: Barry Thomas
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, March 06, 2005 3:17 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Recent acquisition baffles me


I haven't seen any pictures up yet (have I missed something??).

Once upon a time I saw a kowakizashi saya that looked like it was "made of
bamboo". It was, in fact, one of the most skillfully executed lacquer works I
have ever seen. No doubt about it - real urushi. It had leaves and minute ants
also in lacquer - oh, and signed as well. It left me gobsmacked. This was
really, really top class work. Way beyond my pocket...


Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: grandone0 <grandone@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, March 04, 2005 5:04 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Recent acquisition baffles me


I recently acquired a katana that the seller swears is Japanese. He
says it is 130 to 140 yeears old. I've never seen one like it
before. It's saya is made of bamboo...

messages.subject: Recent acquisition baffles me
messages.msgSnippet: I recently acquired a katana that the seller swears is Japanese.  He says it is 130 to 140 yeears old.  I ve never seen one like it before. It s saya is made
messages.messageBody:
I recently acquired a katana that the seller swears is Japanese. He
says it is 130 to 140 yeears old. I've never seen one like it
before. It's saya is made of bamboo. The tsuba is gold or brass with
what look like narcissus flowers and pods. The blade is forged but
doesn't appear to be high-quality steel (hamon is midare). The
kojiri of the saya is flared. The kissaki is O and the mune is
ihori. The boshi is midare-komi on one side and almost Jizo on the
other. Nakago appears to be tanago. The ji has what looks like long
faint lotus flowers decorating it.

More strangely, there is no kashira, same, ito, menuki, on the tsuka,
which I believe is made of wood, rather than bamboo.

I ran the characters past a Korean and a Chinese woman and neither
could tell me anything. No surprise there, however I couldn't
identify the characters in either the Japanese or Chinese character
references on the Web.

If any of you fine scholars can tell me what Ive gotten myself into,
or where it might actually be from and when, I would appreciate it.
Please respond to the group and to my email address:
grandone@... I'm located in the USA.

Thanks so much for reading all this.

Regards,

Jim
